docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved yesterday the first H.I.V. test that uses saliva rather than blood and delivers results in 20 minutes. Public health officials hope the new test will encourage wider and more frequent testing. About 25 percent of all Americans carrying H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, do not know that they are infected, according to estimates by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Around the world, according to the World Health Organization, that figure may be as high as 95 percent.

headline.main: Fast Saliva Test for H.I.V. Gains Federal Approval

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves first HIV test that uses saliva rather than blood and delivers results in 20 minutes; OraSure Technologies, company that developed test, is not yet seeking right to sell it over the counter; OraSure pres Michael Gausling says test is over 99 percent accurate and offers no risk of transmission; Dr Anthony S Fauci, prominent AIDS researcher, praises new test; his photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people see a philosophical or moral element in the debate about whether harming a fetus, through a violent act against its mother, should be a separate crime. In Washington, where the Senate sent a bill to President Bush on March 25 that would designate just such a federal crime, the discussion often drifted toward the symbolic. In places like Utah and other states, though, where this debate has raged for months if not years, people are moving to the next phase: the nuts and bolts of what these laws really mean. And as even the most junior state representative knows, state courts, not federal, are where the vast majority of the country's violent-crime cases are handled.

headline.main: Harm to Fetuses Becomes Issue in Utah and Elsewhere

docs.abstract: Prosecutors in Utah have charged Melissa Ann Rowland with murder in death of one of twins she was pregnant with; say she refused to have Caesarean section despite her doctor's urging until it was too late; people on both sides of abortion debate say they are watching Rowland case closely because of issue at heart: balance between rights of pregnant woman and fetus; 31 states have fetal homicide laws; some supporters of fetal rights say that killing of Laci Peterson and her unborn son in California exposed gap in criminal justice system in some states; map; Rowland photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Miscarriages and induced abortions do not increase a woman's risk of developing breast cancer later in life, according to a study of 83,000 women worldwide being published today. The study's authors, from the University of Oxford in England, said it was the largest to examine the issue, which has been highly charged politically and scientifically.

headline.main: Study Doesn't Link Abortion To Higher Breast Cancer Risk

docs.abstract: Study of 83,000 women conducted at University of Oxford in England shows miscarriages and induced abortions do not increase risk of developing breast cancer later in life; issue has been highly charged scientifically and politically (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A powerful steroid that protects premature infants from chronic lung disease can also lead to long-term neurological damage and severe motor problems, a new study has found. The study, conducted in Taiwan, is the first to trace the long-term effects of the drug dexamethasone, a corticosteroid widely used in the United States to treat inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. The drug has been shown to increase survival in some babies of low birth weight, though research linking it to early neurological damage has prompted doctors to stop using it as often as they once did.

headline.main: Harm Seen in Use of a Steroid To Treat Some Ailing Infants

docs.abstract: Study conducted in Taiwan shows long-term effects of steroid dexamethasone, corticosteroid widely used to protect premature infants from chronic lung disease, leads to long-term neurological damage and severe motor problems; drug is widely used in neonatal care units in US, Europe and Asia (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate approved legislation on Thursday making it a separate offense to harm the fetus in a federal crime committed against a pregnant woman, sending the measure to President Bush for his signature. Opponents denounced the bill, adopted on a vote of 61 to 38, as an effort to undermine the constitutional right to abortion by recognizing the fetus as a person.

headline.main: SENATE OUTLAWS INJURY TO FETUS DURING A CRIME

docs.abstract: Senate, by 61 to 38, approves legislation making it separate offense to harm fetus in federal crime committed against pregnant woman and sends measure to Pres Bush for his signature; opponents denounce bill as effort to undermine constitutional right to abortion by recognizing fetus as a person; bill was passed in House on Feb 26; anti-abortion movement has sought this legislation since 1999; Bush supports measure but Sen John Kerry, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, votes against measure; Sen Mike DeWine, chief Senate author of measure, says bill recognizes that there are two separate victims when pregnant woman is attacked; opponents of measure are troubled by definition of 'child in utero' covered under bill as 'member of the species...at any stage of development'; Sen Dianne Feinstein and others say this definition could ultimately be used as argument to overturn existing laws protecting abortion rights; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Senate approved legislation on Thursday making it a separate offense to harm the fetus in a federal crime committed against a pregnant woman, sending the measure to President Bush for his signature.    Opponents denounced the bill, adopted on a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Annette K. Olesen's women's prison drama, ''In Your Hands,'' like so many Scandinavian films, is heavily shadowed by the titanic influence of Ingmar Bergman. This Danish film, which has its first of three screenings tonight as part of the New Directors/New Films series, explores notions of guilt, faith, superstition and conflicting loyalty with the same do-or-die intensity that has bedeviled several decades of tormented souls in Mr. Bergman's movies. Because the conflicts roil inside the walls of a prison housing glum, angry women, the film quickly establishes a mood of intense claustrophobia, which only deepens as it continues. Anna (Ann Eleonora Jorgensen), the central character, is the institution's idealistic (and annoyingly self-satisfied) new chaplain, who arrives eager to impart cheery spiritual uplift to her depressed flock. Her sermons tend toward glib, inspirational double-talk. Out of one side of her mouth she prates about taking individual responsibility; out of the other she promises the panacea of divine understanding and forgiveness.

headline.main: Torn Between Traditional Faith And a Convict's Bizarre Mysticism

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie In Your Hands, directed by Annette K Olesen and starring Ann Eleonora Jorgensen, part of New Directors/New Films series; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The case might be called Uterus v. Ovum. E and K were a lesbian couple in Marin County, Calif., who wanted children. K provided the eggs, E the womb, and a fertility clinic supplied the sperm and the technical help.

headline.main: Split Gay Couples Face Custody Hurdles

docs.abstract: Same-sex couples who have become parents are increasingly confronting custody disputes that arise after breakup; legal landscape surrounding such breakups is often uncertain or uncharted since laws were not written to anticipate same-sex situations; trauma and confusion suffered by children in conventional divorces can be magnified for children who have grown up with same-sex parents or who are product of earlier heterosexual relationships; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The case might be called Uterus v. Ovum.    E and K were a lesbian couple in Marin County, Calif., who wanted children. K provided the eggs, E the womb, and a fertility clinic supplied the sperm and the technical help.

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and ADAM LIPTAK

docs.lead_paragraph: For the Howard family of Atlanta, this is destiny, an inevitability since the day Dwight Howard was born less than seven months into his mother's pregnancy. ''He was a premature baby, but he was 21 inches long,'' Dwight Howard Sr. said Tuesday at the Moody Bible Institute, where dozens of N.B.A. executives and scouts gathered to watch his son and 20 other high school players perform. ''He's always been big, and from that Sunday morning that he was born, we always said, 'Oh, this boy's going to be an N.B.A. player.' ''

headline.main: 6-11 Prep Star May Be No. 1 In N.B.A. Draft

docs.abstract: Southwest Atlanta Christian Academy (Ga) player Dwight Howard, this year's top high school player in nation, could be selected first in NBA draft; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Joanne Koenig Coste concedes that she is a bit of a Pollyanna. ''It helps with what I do,'' said Ms. Coste, a consultant for institutions that treat patients with dementia and the author of ''Learning to Speak Alzheimer's.''

headline.main: A Wife Learns to See With Alzheimer's Eyes
headline.kicker: A CONVERSATION WITH: JOANNE KOENIG COSTE

docs.abstract: Interview with Joanne Koenig Coste, author of Learning to Speak Alzheimer's, describes her personal experience with husband Charles Koenig, who suffered from Alzheimer's, and her continued work in helping those individuals who care for afflicted; is credited with developing technique called habituation, which is adaptive life style that asks caregiver to live life style of patient not force Alzheimer's patient to try to adjust to rest of world; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Joanne Koenig Coste concedes that she is a bit of a Pollyanna.    ''It helps with what I do,'' said Ms. Coste, a consultant for institutions that treat patients with dementia and the author of ''Learning to Speak Alzheimer's.''
